Having lived in India for two years, I feel there's a lot more material to be reported on here. I did not watch any Bollywood movies in theatres, but I watched loads of Hollywood films; I finally stopped going to the cinema after completely missing the plot of a film one too many times because so much is routinely cut out.

Your example of 'Girl with the dragon tattoo' is interesting, but readers who've seen the film will recognize it as one of the most graphic mainstream films that has come out in a long time. Why not give one of the scores of other examples where films with mild sexual content have been cut to shreds?

For example, we left the theatre after watching George Clooney's ''The American'' completely lost and bewildered; they had cut out every single scene of George's rendezvous with his love interest. So much had been cut out that we did not even know that she was his love interest! That was when I vowed to never watch another meaningful movie in an Indian theatre; I patronized one of the many shops that sold pirated DVDs instead.

Censorship both in theatres and on Indian television is a very interesting subject and I hope NYT delves into it further. It's especially interesting how much effort they put into censoring things of a sexual nature when India is the worst country in the G20 to be a woman, and in the top-three worst countries to be a woman in the world.

Here's another view from Dr. Atkenson at Cornell:
“The trouble with the gas industry’s PR is that it’s built on myths. Myths always have at least a kernel of truth, but you need the rest of the story.
Myth 1. Fracking is a 60-year-old, safe, well proven technology. Yes, fracking is 60 years old. But using this shorthand obscures the truth that what’s at issue here isn’t really just fracking. It's the entire process of coaxing gas from shale using high-volume, slickwater fracking with long laterals (well bore drilled vertically then horizontally) from clustered, multi-well pads. Used together, they form a new process, having been introduced about five six years ago, the jury is still very much out on its safety.
Myth 2. Fluid migration from faulty wells is rare.
Not true. For example, industry researchers examined 352,000 Canadian wells and found sustained casing pressure and gas migration - about 12 per cent of newer wells leaked, considerably more than older wells.
Myth 3. The use of clustered drilling pads reduces surface impacts. False, such pads are large and growing, 10-50 acres or more. and will leave behind clusters of wellheads/holding tanks for decades.
Myth 4. Natural gas is a “clean” fossil fuel
New evidence here is discouraging. NASA scientist D. Shindell’s work shows that methane is 105 times more powerful than CO2 as a global warming contributor over a 20-year time horizon. Leaks happen routinely during regular drilling, fracking and flowback operations."

Dear Mr. Wenz,

The idea that "Simple solar cookers...are a good start." has been tried for 20 years and rejected for thoroughly pragmatic reasons.

Subsistence farmers work from can see to can't see. They need breakfast and hot tea before dawn, when the sun does not yet shine, and they need supper after sundown, when the sun has ceased to shine.

How then does a solar cooker benefit them? They get a cold breakfast with no tea and at best a luke-warm supper congealing after it was cooked some hours before.

In Nepal, this would mean a long day's hard labor at high altitudes without a hot meal or a hot drink.

Would you live this life yourself? Try it before you recommend it to others.
